Comment: I opened with clear intentions to take out a rook.
He began with a slight variation to a common opening move. This caught my attention.
I decided to hide my plan by symmetrizing...which happens to be a word. And hoped he wouldn't notice.
He moved out his bishop, threatening king-side bishop pawn- and looking suspiciously like a 4-move checkmate.

I decided to attack the left side rook, after consideration. I did this, because after planning out the enemies moves, I realized it would prevent the checkmate on me a turn too soon. Giving me no chance at taking the queen.
He moved out his queen, in a motion different then I had seen before. It almost got me but I decided to prepare.
I moved out my f-pawn, stopping the mate.
He took my bishop for a trade
I accepted the trade and continued on my original plan. However, I then learned that the adversaries white bishop would have to be drawn out.
He stole my plan and took my rook easily.
I trapped his piece, however could not threaten the queen.
He developed his rook, realizing he could not escape easily.
I offered a trade, because otherwise, it could have ended much worse.
He accepted the trade and put me in check.
I escaped check 'narrowly' and killed off the queen. However, I was trapped behind a wall of pawns.
He developed towards the middle, not giving the best position, but stopping my plans for the rook attack.
I bellied up to the knight planning a check in my future and forking the rook and king.
He noticed and took advantage of the position.
I moved out, pinning his knights.
He moved back and protected the king.
